profiles.typical_distances_research: Over one-third of child abduction homicide offenders lived within one mile of the victim's residence and more than two-thirds within five miles. Most residential abductions occur within quarter mile of victim's home.
common_routes: Covert approach on foot to the victim's residence from nearby homes, workplaces, or familiar paths
Short movements from the residence to a nearby parked vehicle
Direct travel from the residence or pick-up point to a secondary indoor location (offender's home, vacant building) or nearby outdoor area (field, woods, park)
Residential movement within the home or neighborhood
transportation_methods: Walking the victim away from the residence, especially to nearby outdoor locations
Use of a motor vehicle parked close to the residence; in many cases, the vehicle is owned by or routinely available to the offender
Short vehicle trips within the same general area rather than long-distance or interstate transport

profiles.typical_distances_research: Custodial abductions often involve regional to interstate movement, especially when crossing state lines or moving to another city/state. Stereotypical kidnappings involve 50+ miles or overnight detention.
common_routes: Travel from the child's home or yard into nearby streets, highways, or parking lots
Local vehicle travel along highways and through community parking areas where initial contact or abduction occurs
Highway travel for custodial abductions moving to extended family locations or home country
Interstate routes for family abductions crossing state lines
transportation_methods: Private motor vehicles (cars, trucks) used to move victims along highways and to and from parking lots and other locations
Occasional use of rental cars, borrowed vehicles, or rarely stolen vehicles to transport the victim
Long-distance vehicle travel for custodial and stereotypical kidnappings

profiles.typical_distances_research: Most cases involve local or regional movement within the same city, county, or nearby area. Sexual offenders typically stay local (<5 miles, often within 1 mile).
common_routes: Short-distance movements from residential locations to nearby public or semi-public spaces and back
Travel from the child's home or yard into nearby streets, highways, or parking lots
Routes to and from school or other routine activities (walking routes, bus stops, paths to friends' houses)
transportation_methods: On-foot movement from homes into nearby streets, yards, or parking areas, especially in urban or suburban neighborhoods
Short vehicle trips within the same general area
Public transit for some acquaintance abductions
Local vehicle travel within neighborhood or city
